water: Limit your showers to less than 10 minutes by using a shower timer.
Wash clothes in full loads to avoid wasting water.
Opt for water wise plants in your garden such as succulents.
If there's a spike in your water bill, there may be a leak somewhere in your house.
Fill your sink with water to hand wash dishes, instead of letting the water run while you're scrubbing.
Water plants in the early morning so water evaporates less.
Choose efficient water fixtures (shower heads, faucets, etc.).
electricity: Look for ENERGY STAR label on products that use energy because they meet strict efficiency guidelines.
Plug home electronics such as TVs into power strips.
Change your lightbults to CFL bulbs. They use 75% less energy and last up to 10 times longer than traditional bulbs.
Keep curtains or shades open to use daylighting instead of turning on lights.
Air dry your dishes. Most of the energy used by a dishwasher is for water heating.
Look into smart appliances that can be connected to smart electric meters of home energy management systems.
Cover liquids and wrap foods stored in the refrigerator, as uncovered foods release moisture and make the compressor work harder.
Consider air drying clothes. Dryers use an average 1000 kwh/year.
Turn off and unplug appliances when they are not in use.
gas: Lower the thermostat on your water heater to 120 F.
Save as much as 10% a year on heating and cooling by turning your thermostat back 7-10 F for 8 hours a day.
Close your curtains and shades facing the sun to keep your home cool during the summer and reduce the need for air conditioning.
Wash clothes in cold water whenever possible.
